Location: Silicon Valley, CA

Price range: ~55k

Lease or Buy: Buy

New or used: New or certified pre-owned.

Type of vehicle: Sedan/sports car

Must haves: Leather, preferably some cargo room, luxurious/smooth

Desired transmission: Auto but OK with manual

Intended use: Daily Driver

Vehicles you've already considered: Tesla Model 3, Lexus IS 350, Kia Stinger, Genesis G70, Audi S4

Is this your 1st vehicle: No.

Do you need a Warranty: Preferably.

Can you do Minor work on your own vehicle: Yes

Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: No

Additonal Notes: Had a 2012 Golf GTI w/ Autobahn trim that got rear ended and totaled. I'm leaning pretty heavily towards the Model 3, but all I've been seeing lately about Tesla has been negative news. Is any car right now just an absolute great deal for the money given the segment that I'm looking in that makes it worth it over the Model 3? Interior of IS 350 was pretty meh, and I was not a fan of the visibility in the Stinger whatsoever.

• Additional Notes: looking for something to replace my dying lemon of a 2008 impreza before it totally dies, so I'd probably prefer to try and trade that than try to sell it. I really like the manual in it, but in traffic it gets rough. Adaptive cruise would be a great thing as well
comment_body.9:
Location: Chicago/Urbana, Il

Price range: Under 6k

Lease or Buy: Buy

Type of vehicles: coupe, hatchback, something small

Must haves: cheap to repair, somewhat reliable, tall person accessible

Transmission: Auto

Use: DD

Considered: Fiat 500, Smart ForTwo, Kia Soul

1st vehicle: Yes

Warranty: Nope

Minor work: Yeah, probably

Major work: No

My sister is looking for her first car. She wants something small, cute, fuel efficient. I'm buying, so I want something cheap that won't cause her too many problems or be too expensive to fix. She found a 2013 Smart ForTwo with around 30k miles for 6k, but we're both kinda tall (which may be a problem? idk), and I want a few options. Neither of us know how to drive stick, but I see that's a popular choice on these sorts of cars.

  • Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: (engine and transmission, timing belt/chains, body work, suspension etc ) Not really

  • Additional Notes:

comment_body.73:
First time poster and am looking for some feedback.

Toronto, Canada

I’ve currently got a 2014 VW Touareg TDI with 135,00 kms on it. It’s done me very well over the past few years and I really like the ride/diesel mpg.

I’ve got an opportunity to take a 2016 SQ5 with 38,000 kms off a friend for a great deal ($20k) which would be about what I’d get for my VW.

I’ve driven the SQ5 for a week now and it feels like a car with much more pep and slightly less room in the trunk. The appealing part for me is the low kms, I understand the TDI can go to 300k no issues with the right Maintence but I’m wondering what r/cars thinks of this. Does it sound like a worthwhile change up or should I stick with the Touareg?

Any opinions are very welcome!

Keeping my Accord, but want this one to be as cheap as possible to run/insure, while still being reasonably comfortable. Collector insurance will run less than $25/month, compared to $140/mo I pay right now on my Accord. So it HAS TO BE pre-1996.. RWD with 90's Traction Control in the winter isn't great if my wife needs to take it sometimes.

I travel for work and will probably pick it up anywhere between Edmonton and Montreal and drive it back home, so rarity isn't a huge concern if it's the right car.
